did.unittitle: Dept. of Romance Languages and Literatures (University of Michigan) records 1907-2003, 1920-1970
did.abstract: Records of the University of Michigan Department of Romance Languages and Literatures. The collection contains administrative and topical files of the Department, records of associated student organizations, photographs, and audio material. Of particular note is the extensive run of photographs (1908-1955) of photographs of the Cercle Français' annual French-language play.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The records of the Department of Romance Languages and Literatures were received in 1999. Donor no. 8871.

accessrestrict.p: The records are open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Dept. of Romance Languages and Literatures (University of Michigan) Records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The first modern language taught at the University of Michigan was French, offered in 1847 by Louis Fasquelle. Spanish, Italian, Portuguese and German were added sporadically over the next four decades, taught by Fasquelle and other appointed instructors. In 1887 the Regents granted a petition for the official and separate formations of the Department of Romance Languages and Literatures and the Department of Germanic Languages and Literatures. Special courses in French, Spanish and German for engineering students were created in 1889. From 1904 until 1928 these courses were taught by a professor of modern languages within Engineering. In 1928, however, this responsibility was transferred back to each respective department in the College of Literature, Science and the Arts. The Department of Romance Languages and Literatures has continued to offer instruction in the languages, literatures, and civilizations of France, Spain, Latin America, Italy, and Portugal, with occasional courses in such fields as Rumanian, Catalan, and Francophone areas outside of France. Graduate courses have been offered since 1858, when the first advanced coursework in French was offered. In 1949 a program in Romance Linguistics was added to the department, including undergraduate coursework and a separate graduate degree program. This program is not currently offered.

The department has additionally been involved in several programs over the years. With the beginning of World War II, special language training courses were developed in all sections of the department for students soon to enter into military service. These courses continued until 1945. In the summer of 1942, staff from the department provided language and area studies for the Civil Affairs Specialist Training Program and language training for the Army Specialist Training Program. A special program was also set up during postwar years for the training of field officers for various postwar assignments in Latin America. In the summer of 1956 the department took an active part in the national Foreign Language in the Elementary School program, establishing training programs for elementary school teachers in the instruction of French and Spanish. In the summer of 1959 the department ran an institute supported by the National Defense Education Act offering special remedial training to high school language teachers and superintendents.

Extracurricular student activities have been active at different points in the department's history. The Cercle Français was organized in 1902 by and for students of French. This organization was particularly active from the 1930s through the 1950s, supported by both the University and City of Ann Arbor communities and producing an annual play and an annual French lecture series. Spanish organizations such as Sigma Delta Pi, the national Spanish honor society, and the Sociedad Hispanica, were active as well during this time.

Today the Department of Romance Languages and Literatures offers courses in French, Italian, Portuguese, Spanish, and Romance Linguistics, focusing on language, literature, and culture. For current information about the department, see the department web site, located at the following URL: http://www.lsa.umich.edu/rll .

For more detailed information on the history of the department, particularly the early years, see the University of Michigan Encyclopedic Survey, and the folder entitled "Department History" located in Box 2 of this record group.

scopecontent.p: The records of the Department of 77Romance Language provide some documentation of the administration of the department and several student organizations including Sigma Delta Pi, the Sociedad Hispanica and the Cercle Français. This record group is divided into five series: Department Administration, Faculty Information, Student Organizations, Topical, and Audio-Visual.

scopecontent.p: Department Administration is the largest series in this record group, spanning 1 linear foot, and contains materials from the years 1926 to 1986, with sporadic concentrations of material from across those years in different areas. Subseries within this series include budget and salary information from the years 1970-1986, committee records and correspondence, including a substantial run of Executive Committee minutes and materials from 1933 to 1944; course administration materials, including enrollment and courseload statistics from 1947 to 1983; department reports, including the "Report on Department Activities" 1926 to 1927 and 1928 to 1931; graduate program information; and position requests, 1984-1986.

did.unittitle: Senior Advisory and Executive Committee Meetings 1954-1958
Report on Present and Future Staff Arrangements 1952

scopecontent.p: Faculty Information spans the years from 1941 to 1981. This series includes bibliographies of publications by faculty members from 1852 to 1965, evaluations by students and by the professors themselves, information on faculty members holding foreign degrees and faculty members who know Russian, faculty personnel records 1941-1942, and promotion requests, 1942-1952.

Student Organizations spans the years 1924 to 1965, and includes materials from two organizations. The Sigma Delta Pi subseries includes membership information, accounts and correspondence between 1948 and 1964. A file of photographs from this organization has been removed to the Audio-visual series. The Sociedad Hispanica subseries includes records, correspondence, and miscellany including play programs and tickets to lecture series, spanning 1924 to 1965. Photographs from this subseries have also been removed to the Audio-visual series. Cercle Franççais, a French language organization, is represented in the Audio-Visual series.

The Topical series includes materials on various topics of departmental concern from 1928 to 1975. Notable within this series are a Departmental History file including a letter confirming the consolidation of the Department in 1928, and an extensive run of correspondence documenting University Lectures related to the department from 1956 to 1975. Also within this series are programs and correspondence from 1963-1987 (including such notable people as Barbara Jordan, Beverly Sills, Alice Walker, Toni Morrison, and Emmanuel Le Roy Ladurie) related to the Hayward Keniston Lectures.

did.unittitle: Summer Study Programs in France and Spain 1980
Tardiness to Class in Frieze Building 1958
Teaching of Foreign Languages in Elementary Schools 1955

scopecontent.p: Audio-Visual includes sound recordings and photographs. Photographs span the years from 1908 to 1964, and document student organizations and some staff and faculty. Notable is a run of pictures of the Cercle Français plays, 1908-1956. Audio materials include a record on Spanish pronunciation, and magnetic tape reels in French used in 1968.

The Audio-Visual series includes sound recordings and photographs. Photographs span the years from 1914 to 1964, and document student organizations. Notable is a run of pictures of the Cercle Français plays, 1914-1956. Audio materials include a record on Spanish pronunciation, and magnetic tape reels in French used in 1968.

scopecontent.p: The Department of Romance Languages and Literatures Publications series is divided into four subseries: Bibliographies, Brochures, Flyers, and Newsletters.

The Brochures subseries contains paper brochures that advertise the department. The Flyers subseries contains flyers that would be mailed or posted in order to advertise Department events such as lectures.

The Newsletters subseries is further subdivided by publication title. The Department of Romance Languages and Literatures is a 2003 newsletter most likely mailed to alumni. The Department Weekly Calendar and Announcement was a weekly newsletter containing a list of Department and University events such as speakers, Department-related announcements ranging from calls for papers to classifieds. El Bitoque and El Campanario are Spanish-language publications from 1955. Romance Language News is a periodic publication from 1989-1994 and The Weekly Tongue appears to be its predecessor from 1977-1981. Volumes 2 and 3 of the Weekly Tongue are found loose in folders and also are bound in their entirely.
